sub_strands.name: Introduction to Biology
topics: Fields of study and careers related to Biology
specific_learning_outcomes: Explain the application of Biology in everyday life
Relate fields of study in Biology to career opportunities
Illustrate the careers related to fields of study in Biology
Appreciate the importance of Biology in everyday life
key_inquiry_questions: Why is it important to study Biology?
suggested_learning_experiences: Search for information on the meaning and application of Biology in everyday life and share with peers
Collaboratively search for information from print and non-print media on fields of study in Biology and relate them to career opportunities
Use locally available materials to design a career wheel to relate fields of study in Biology to careers and make presentations
Discuss the factors that influence career choices (interest, ability)
core_competencies: Imagination and Creativity: Visualises prospective fields and careers using flashcards and career wheels
Self-efficacy: Develops self-awareness discussing factors influencing career choices
values: Respect: Appreciates diverse opinions during discussions
Responsibility: Searches for information from safe sources
sub_strands.key_concepts: Biology has wide applications in everyday life and offers diverse career opportunities in various fields of study.

sub_strands.name: Specimen Collection and Preservation
topics: Project on collecting, processing and preserving biological specimens
specific_learning_outcomes: Identify apparatus and materials used for collecting, processing and preserving specimens
Collect, process, and preserve specimens for biological studies using improvised and conventional apparatus
Appreciate the importance of collecting, processing, and preserving specimens in Biology
key_inquiry_questions: How are specimens collected and preserved?
suggested_learning_experiences: Search for information on apparatus and materials for collecting specimens
Improvise apparatus from locally available materials for collecting, processing, and preserving specimens
Observe designated road crossing points while collecting specimens
Make a herbarium to preserve specimens
Carry out a project documenting specimen collection and preservation
core_competencies: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving: Improvises apparatus to address shortages
Self-efficacy: Gains confidence while collecting, processing, and preserving specimens
values: Unity: Collaborates with peers during collection activities
Integrity: Enhances honesty during the project
sub_strands.key_concepts: Proper collection, processing, and preservation of specimens is essential for accurate biological studies and research.

sub_strands.name: Cell Structure and Specialisation
topics: Preparation of slides for observation under a microscope
Estimation of cell size during microscopy
Differences between light and electron microscope
Cell structure observed under electron microscope
Differences between plant and animal cells
Specialised cells in plants and animals (adaptations to their functions)
Cell organisation (organelles, cells, tissues, organs, organ systems)
specific_learning_outcomes: Differentiate between light and electron microscope as used in studying cell structure
Prepare temporary slides and estimate cell size using light microscope
Describe structure and functions of plant and animal cells under electron microscope
Relate the structures of specialised cells to their functions
Appreciate the cell as the basic unit of life
key_inquiry_questions: Why do plant and animal cells differ?
suggested_learning_experiences: Carry out experiments on preparation of specimen slides
Observe and draw plant and animal cells
Use photomicrographs/charts to compare structures
Model the structure of cells and observe specialised cells
Discuss levels of organisation in organisms
core_competencies: Communication and Collaboration: Cooperates in groups comparing cell structures
Digital Literacy: Gains digital literacy researching microscopes
values: Respect: Demonstrates tolerance during discussions
Responsibility: Searches for reliable information
sub_strands.key_concepts: The cell is the basic unit of life. Plant and animal cells have different structures adapted to their functions. Cells are organised into tissues, organs, and organ systems.

sub_strands.name: Chemicals of Life
topics: Composition, properties and functions of chemicals of life (Carbohydrates, Lipids, Proteins, Vitamins)
Functions of water and mineral salts
specific_learning_outcomes: Describe the composition, properties, and functions of chemicals of life
Investigate the presence of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and vitamin C in food substances
Investigate the presence of enzymes in living tissues
Determine factors affecting enzymatic reactions
Appreciate the importance of chemical components in cells
key_inquiry_questions: How are chemicals important in cells?
How is the presence of chemicals of life determined?
suggested_learning_experiences: Search and discuss information on chemical components in cells
Carry out experiments to test for carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and vitamin C
Investigate presence of catalase enzymes in tissues
Determine factors affecting enzyme activity and discuss results
Examine packaging labels to evaluate chemical content in food
core_competencies: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving: Analyses experiments and draws inferences
Learning to Learn: Evaluates packaging labels of food products
values: Love: Shares resources and ideas during experiments
Unity: Collaborates with others during investigations
sub_strands.key_concepts: Chemicals of life (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, vitamins, water, mineral salts) have specific compositions, properties, and functions essential for life. Enzymes are biological catalysts whose activity is affected by various factors.

sub_strands.name: Nutrition
specific_learning_outcomes: Describe types of nutrition in plants
Relate structure of chloroplast to function
Illustrate light and dark stages of photosynthesis
Appreciate significance of photosynthesis in nature
suggested_learning_experiences: Search for information on plant nutrition and share with peers
Discuss chloroplast structure and function
Watch videos/animations of photosynthesis and discuss
Discuss reactions during light and dark stages using illustrations
core_competencies: Self-Efficacy: Performs tasks using illustrations
Digital Literacy: Uses digital devices for research
values: Unity: Cooperates with peers
Respect: Shows patience listening to peers
sub_strands.key_concepts: Plants obtain food through photosynthesis, which occurs in chloroplasts. The process involves light and dark stages with specific biochemical reactions.

sub_strands.name: Transport
topics: Vascular tissues in monocots and dicots
Uptake of water and mineral salts
specific_learning_outcomes: Relate structures to functions in transport
Illustrate vascular arrangement in monocots and dicots
Demonstrate water and mineral uptake
Demonstrate factors affecting transpiration
Describe translocation of food
Appreciate significance of transport
key_inquiry_questions: How are materials transported in plants?
suggested_learning_experiences: Observe plant structures using microscope
Carry out experiments on water uptake and transpiration
Demonstrate translocation using safe experiments
core_competencies: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving: Analyse experimental results
Imagination and Creativity: Seeks clarification during experiments
values: Responsibility: Takes care of plants during experiments
Integrity: Honest in reporting results
sub_strands.key_concepts: Plants have specialized vascular tissues (xylem and phloem) for transporting water, minerals, and manufactured food. Transpiration and translocation are key transport processes.

sub_strands.name: Gaseous Exchange and Respiration
topics: Structure, adaptations and functions of gaseous exchange sites
Mechanism of opening and closing of stomata
specific_learning_outcomes: Relate structure of gaseous exchange sites to function
Describe stomata mechanism
Investigate aerobic and anaerobic respiration
Explain economic importance of anaerobic respiration
Appreciate significance of gaseous exchange and respiration
key_inquiry_questions: Why is gaseous exchange important to plants?
How is respiration useful to plants?
suggested_learning_experiences: Observe and discuss adaptations of gaseous exchange sites
Carry out experiments on aerobic and anaerobic respiration
Perform fermentation project using locally available materials
core_competencies: Communication and Collaboration: Cooperates in group discussions
Learning to Learn: Applies acquired knowledge in projects
values: Responsibility: Disposes experimental products properly
Social justice: Ensures fairness in group activities
sub_strands.key_concepts: Plants exchange gases through specialized structures. They carry out aerobic and anaerobic respiration to release energy. Anaerobic respiration has economic applications.

sub_strands.name: Nutrition
specific_learning_outcomes: Relate structure of mouthparts and beaks to feeding functions
Illustrate mouthparts in different insects
Appreciate diversity in feeding modes
key_inquiry_questions: How do insects and birds feed?
suggested_learning_experiences: Observe insect mouthparts under microscope and discuss
Watch animations/videos on feeding adaptations
core_competencies: Communication and Collaboration: Cooperates during observations
Digital Literacy: Uses digital devices for research
values: Responsibility: Observes safety precautions
Social Justice: Ensures equity in group activities
sub_strands.key_concepts: Different animals have specialized feeding structures adapted to their diet and feeding habits. Insects have diverse mouthparts and birds have various beak types suited to their feeding modes.

sub_strands.name: Transport
topics: Transport systems in insects, fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals
Pumping mechanism of the mammalian heart
specific_learning_outcomes: Explain importance of transport in animals
Illustrate animal transport systems
Describe mammalian heart pumping mechanism
Explain blood clotting and blood groups
Appreciate diversity of transport systems
key_inquiry_questions: Why is transport important in animals?
suggested_learning_experiences: Research animal transport systems
Dissect and observe transport systems safely
Illustrate and share findings with peers
core_competencies: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving: Analyses compatibility of blood donors
Self-efficacy: Gains confidence during dissections
values: Love: Respects peers during research
Peace: Demonstrates tolerance during dissections
sub_strands.key_concepts: Animals have different transport systems adapted to their complexity and environment. The mammalian circulatory system includes heart, blood vessels, and blood with specific mechanisms for pumping, clotting, and immune response.

sub_strands.name: Gaseous Exchange and Respiration
topics: Respiratory substrates and determination of respiratory quotient
Investigating factors affecting rate of respiration
specific_learning_outcomes: Explain characteristics of respiratory surfaces
Describe adaptations of respiratory structures
Describe gaseous exchange mechanism
Describe aerobic and anaerobic respiration
Calculate respiratory quotient
Appreciate importance of gaseous exchange and respiration
key_inquiry_questions: How does gaseous exchange occur in animals?
Why is respiration important to animals?
suggested_learning_experiences: Observe and discuss respiratory structures in various animals
Carry out experiments on respiration and energy requirement
Construct models demonstrating gaseous exchange
core_competencies: Communication and Collaboration: Shares information during group activities
Learning to Learn: Develops relationships while working in groups
values: Respect: Considerate of others' opinions
Responsibility: Engages in assigned roles
sub_strands.key_concepts: Animals have specialized respiratory surfaces for gaseous exchange. Respiration releases energy through aerobic and anaerobic pathways. The respiratory quotient varies depending on the substrate used.
